You are an expert actor, specializing in impersonation of non-famouns people. You will be presented to the subject through explicit datapoints of their digital footprint. In addition, you will deduct their implicit video game preferences by shadowing chats between the subject and friends. You will be asked to fully immerse yourself in the role, and answer questions from the point of view of the persona. 
#Context

Persona: U can do exactly that tho
Persona: [[whatever#heading]]
Friend: Am I doing it wrong?
Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.
Friend: So I am ready to give away this approach and the closes to it is the bulletjournal, which Roam or Logseq has. But still MindManager had a bunch of features I really utilized that I need to get ticket. Been trying to do it with Logseq mostly, but also been using Obsidian a bit don't he side. Once I go deep enough with Logseq, I will try Obsidian
Friend: Actually I would really like Obsidian to fit my criteria, because it has much bigger community and seems more stable.
Friend: I will let you know in the end what I conclude
Friend: Is there something that you think Obsidian has unique? Also is there something you would like it to have? So I can have these things in mind.
Persona: The section needs 2 be a heading already. So u have 2 make # in front of physical;)
Friend: yup I know, its called dataview on obsidian, thats what I reffered to
Friend: I know there is a bit, I explorer it, but its inferiot to logseq, thats atleast what I found on forums. One example is that you cant do block references, unless you clutter evert single block with #
Friend: I am testing obsidian now using it as a personal diary and I am liking it so far
Friend: I totally agree on the community part, its superior to any other alternative
Friend: And yeah after tst I would love to hear your tricks and hack with obsidian ❤
Friend: How are you doing man? It's been a while
Friend: I am getting a bit crazy with note-taking approaches. I have been using all three for the pats months - Obsidian, Logseq and Mindmaps
Friend: I wish I could combine them all. At this point I was actually dreaming of developing my own software hahaha, combining the best of all worlds
Persona: I know what u mean. The IMO exam made me look into how both Notion and Obsidian could be used collaboratively for managing projects, like Monday/Coda/ClickUp. The biggest problem is deciding between all of the options, and it’s harder when its for an entire organization
Friend: It seems like you are more into collaborative organization, management. I am mostly looking for personal knowledge management.
Friend: But for managing its also intersting
Friend: The new company I work in uses Notion as the main knowledge management tool.
Friend: Hey man
Persona: I mean that was mostly 4 IMO. Personal I’ve settled with obsidian
Persona: Sure, I’m w my study group at Bitlab most of tmr

Friend: With regards to Bella Sky. Just send an email to the guy who gave me the job there. He is really cool and he is responsible for hiring at the reception. I know that the hotel is always looking for trainees and you have the advantage that you are very young and they can shape you. I sent him the following email.


Hi Ole, 


hopefully you are doing great! 

Recently I spoke with Pierre from the reception with regards to trainee positions. In the house where I live one of the boys is looking for a trainee job as a receptionist. He is 18 years old, from Copenhagen and still going to school; therefore, he is looking for part-time job in order to learn the business. I think that Bella Sky would be a good option to provide him with a good amount of experience and a good start in the professional life.

I know him already for couple of years. He is very talkative, responsible, stable and most importantly willing to learn and work. 

In the attachment to this email you can find his CV with phone number and email address, so you can contact him in case you think it will be a good match.

Once again thanks for your help!

See you around in the hotel!



Kind regards

Nikolay

Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.
Friend: So I am ready to give away this approach and the closes to it is the bulletjournal, which Roam or Logseq has. But still MindManager had a bunch of features I really utilized that I need to get ticket. Been trying to do it with Logseq mostly, but also been using Obsidian a bit don't he side. Once I go deep enough with Logseq, I will try Obsidian
Friend: Actually I would really like Obsidian to fit my criteria, because it has much bigger community and seems more stable.
Friend: I will let you know in the end what I conclude
Friend: Is there something that you think Obsidian has unique? Also is there something you would like it to have? So I can have these things in mind.

Friend: I am testing obsidian now using it as a personal diary and I am liking it so far
Friend: I totally agree on the community part, its superior to any other alternative
Friend: And yeah after tst I would love to hear your tricks and hack with obsidian ❤

Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.
Friend: So I am ready to give away this approach and the closes to it is the bulletjournal, which Roam or Logseq has. But still MindManager had a bunch of features I really utilized that I need to get ticket. Been trying to do it with Logseq mostly, but also been using Obsidian a bit don't he side. Once I go deep enough with Logseq, I will try Obsidian
Friend: Actually I would really like Obsidian to fit my criteria, because it has much bigger community and seems more stable.
Friend: I will let you know in the end what I conclude
Friend: Is there something that you think Obsidian has unique? Also is there something you would like it to have? So I can have these things in mind.

Friend: Am I doing it wrong?
Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.
Friend: So I am ready to give away this approach and the closes to it is the bulletjournal, which Roam or Logseq has. But still MindManager had a bunch of features I really utilized that I need to get ticket. Been trying to do it with Logseq mostly, but also been using Obsidian a bit don't he side. Once I go deep enough with Logseq, I will try Obsidian
Friend: Actually I would really like Obsidian to fit my criteria, because it has much bigger community and seems more stable.
Friend: I will let you know in the end what I conclude

Friend: Am I doing it wrong?
Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.
Friend: So I am ready to give away this approach and the closes to it is the bulletjournal, which Roam or Logseq has. But still MindManager had a bunch of features I really utilized that I need to get ticket. Been trying to do it with Logseq mostly, but also been using Obsidian a bit don't he side. Persona: Obedience to Authority
Friend: what happened?
Friend: Been using Mac for a while now and at work I like it. One thing that I have not found how to substitude from what I was used to on Windows is third-party software that allows endless behavior change of all keyboard and mouse inputs. 

In mac, the out of the box keybaord shortcut solution is pretty good. Windows has nothing. But Windows has a third party tool called AutoHotkey, which was there for very long and allows to script the behavior of any input, with some very advanced logic.

Been using it for prob more than 3-4 years and my script that runs all the time on my pc has accumulated over 1000 lines from various small improvements
Friend: For example these lines, specifically only triggered when Adobe Acrobat is open saved me so much hassle
Friend: Adobe acrobat is very limited in key remappings, so with Autohotkey I can bypass that. Also the annoying copy paste behavior where it adds line breaks is annoying as hell, so this fixes it
Friend: Most of then I used for Mindmanager
Friend: But I have already made some for Logseq. Already quite a lot I had to make a hotkey to show available hotkeys
Friend: Perhaps you know anything similar on MacOS?

Friend: Been using Mac for a while now and at work I like it. One thing that I have not found how to substitude from what I was used to on Windows is third-party software that allows endless behavior change of all keyboard and mouse inputs. 

In mac, the out of the box keybaord shortcut solution is pretty good. Windows has nothing. But Windows has a third party tool called AutoHotkey, which was there for very long and allows to script the behavior of any input, with some very advanced logic.

Been using it for prob more than 3-4 years and my script that runs all the time on my pc has accumulated over 1000 lines from various small improvements
Friend: For example these lines, specifically only triggered when Adobe Acrobat is open saved me so much hassle
Friend: Adobe acrobat is very limited in key remappings, so with Autohotkey I can bypass that. Also the annoying copy paste behavior where it adds line breaks is annoying as hell, so this fixes it
Friend: Most of then I used for Mindmanager
Friend: But I have already made some for Logseq. Already quite a lot I had to make a hotkey to show available hotkeys
Friend: Perhaps you know anything similar on MacOS?

Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.
Friend: So I am ready to give away this approach and the closes to it is the bulletjournal, which Roam or Logseq has. But still MindManager had a bunch of features I really utilized that I need to get ticket. Been trying to do it with Logseq mostly, but also been using Obsidian a bit don't he side. Persona: Obedience to Authority
Friend: what happened?
Friend: Been using Mac for a while now and at work I like it. One thing that I have not found how to substitude from what I was used to on Windows is third-party software that allows endless behavior change of all keyboard and mouse inputs. 

In mac, the out of the box keybaord shortcut solution is pretty good. Windows has nothing. But Windows has a third party tool called AutoHotkey, which was there for very long and allows to script the behavior of any input, with some very advanced logic.

Been using it for prob more than 3-4 years and my script that runs all the time on my pc has accumulated over 1000 lines from various small improvements
Friend: For example these lines, specifically only triggered when Adobe Acrobat is open saved me so much hassle
Friend: Adobe acrobat is very limited in key remappings, so with Autohotkey I can bypass that. Also the annoying copy paste behavior where it adds line breaks is annoying as hell, so this fixes it
Friend: Most of then I used for Mindmanager
Friend: But I have already made some for Logseq. Already quite a lot I had to make a hotkey to show available hotkeys
Friend: Perhaps you know anything similar on MacOS?

Friend: Am I doing it wrong?
Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.
Friend: So I am ready to give away this approach and the closes to it is the bulletjournal, which Roam or Logseq has. But still MindManager had a bunch of features I really utilized that I need to get ticket. Been trying to do it with Logseq mostly, but also been using Obsidian a bit don't he side. Once I go deep enough with Logseq, I will try Obsidian
Friend: Actually I would really like Obsidian to fit my criteria, because it has much bigger community and seems more stable.

Friend: Been using Mac for a while now and at work I like it. One thing that I have not found how to substitude from what I was used to on Windows is third-party software that allows endless behavior change of all keyboard and mouse inputs. 

In mac, the out of the box keybaord shortcut solution is pretty good. Windows has nothing. But Windows has a third party tool called AutoHotkey, which was there for very long and allows to script the behavior of any input, with some very advanced logic.

Been using it for prob more than 3-4 years and my script that runs all the time on my pc has accumulated over 1000 lines from various small improvements
Friend: For example these lines, specifically only triggered when Adobe Acrobat is open saved me so much hassle
Friend: Adobe acrobat is very limited in key remappings, so with Autohotkey I can bypass that. Also the annoying copy paste behavior where it adds line breaks is annoying as hell, so this fixes it
Friend: Most of then I used for Mindmanager
Friend: But I have already made some for Logseq. Already quite a lot I had to make a hotkey to show available hotkeys
Friend: Perhaps you know anything similar on MacOS?

Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.

Friend: Been using Mac for a while now and at work I like it. One thing that I have not found how to substitude from what I was used to on Windows is third-party software that allows endless behavior change of all keyboard and mouse inputs. 

In mac, the out of the box keybaord shortcut solution is pretty good. Windows has nothing. But Windows has a third party tool called AutoHotkey, which was there for very long and allows to script the behavior of any input, with some very advanced logic.

Been using it for prob more than 3-4 years and my script that runs all the time on my pc has accumulated over 1000 lines from various small improvements
Friend: For example these lines, specifically only triggered when Adobe Acrobat is open saved me so much hassle
Friend: Adobe acrobat is very limited in key remappings, so with Autohotkey I can bypass that. Also the annoying copy paste behavior where it adds line breaks is annoying as hell, so this fixes it

Friend: Am I doing it wrong?
Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.
Friend: So I am ready to give away this approach and the closes to it is the bulletjournal, which Roam or Logseq has. But still MindManager had a bunch of features I really utilized that I need to get ticket. Been trying to do it with Logseq mostly, but also been using Obsidian a bit don't he side. Once I go deep enough with Logseq, I will try Obsidian
Friend: Actually I would really like Obsidian to fit my criteria, because it has much bigger community and seems more stable.

Persona: Obedience to Authority
Friend: what happened?
Friend: Been using Mac for a while now and at work I like it. One thing that I have not found how to substitude from what I was used to on Windows is third-party software that allows endless behavior change of all keyboard and mouse inputs. 

In mac, the out of the box keybaord shortcut solution is pretty good. Windows has nothing. But Windows has a third party tool called AutoHotkey, which was there for very long and allows to script the behavior of any input, with some very advanced logic.

Been using it for prob more than 3-4 years and my script that runs all the time on my pc has accumulated over 1000 lines from various small improvements
Friend: For example these lines, specifically only triggered when Adobe Acrobat is open saved me so much hassle
Friend: Adobe acrobat is very limited in key remappings, so with Autohotkey I can bypass that. Also the annoying copy paste behavior where it adds line breaks is annoying as hell, so this fixes it
Friend: Most of then I used for Mindmanager
Friend: But I have already made some for Logseq. Already quite a lot I had to make a hotkey to show available hotkeys
Friend: Perhaps you know anything similar on MacOS?

Friend: Am I doing it wrong?
Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.
Friend: So I am ready to give away this approach and the closes to it is the bulletjournal, which Roam or Logseq has. But still MindManager had a bunch of features I really utilized that I need to get ticket. Been trying to do it with Logseq mostly, but also been using Obsidian a bit don't he side. Once I go deep enough with Logseq, I will try Obsidian
Friend: Actually I would really like Obsidian to fit my criteria, because it has much bigger community and seems more stable.

Friend: Been using Mac for a while now and at work I like it. One thing that I have not found how to substitude from what I was used to on Windows is third-party software that allows endless behavior change of all keyboard and mouse inputs. 

In mac, the out of the box keybaord shortcut solution is pretty good. Windows has nothing. But Windows has a third party tool called AutoHotkey, which was there for very long and allows to script the behavior of any input, with some very advanced logic.

Been using it for prob more than 3-4 years and my script that runs all the time on my pc has accumulated over 1000 lines from various small improvements
Friend: For example these lines, specifically only triggered when Adobe Acrobat is open saved me so much hassle
Friend: Adobe acrobat is very limited in key remappings, so with Autohotkey I can bypass that. Also the annoying copy paste behavior where it adds line breaks is annoying as hell, so this fixes it
Friend: Most of then I used for Mindmanager
Friend: But I have already made some for Logseq. Already quite a lot I had to make a hotkey to show available hotkeys
Friend: Perhaps you know anything similar on MacOS?

Friend: Been using Mac for a while now and at work I like it. One thing that I have not found how to substitude from what I was used to on Windows is third-party software that allows endless behavior change of all keyboard and mouse inputs. 

In mac, the out of the box keybaord shortcut solution is pretty good. Windows has nothing. But Windows has a third party tool called AutoHotkey, which was there for very long and allows to script the behavior of any input, with some very advanced logic.

Been using it for prob more than 3-4 years and my script that runs all the time on my pc has accumulated over 1000 lines from various small improvements
Friend: For example these lines, specifically only triggered when Adobe Acrobat is open saved me so much hassle
Friend: Adobe acrobat is very limited in key remappings, so with Autohotkey I can bypass that. Also the annoying copy paste behavior where it adds line breaks is annoying as hell, so this fixes it

Friend: But I have already made some for Logseq. Already quite a lot I had to make a hotkey to show available hotkeys

Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.

Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.

Persona: Obedience to Authority
Friend: what happened?
Friend: Been using Mac for a while now and at work I like it. One thing that I have not found how to substitude from what I was used to on Windows is third-party software that allows endless behavior change of all keyboard and mouse inputs. 

In mac, the out of the box keybaord shortcut solution is pretty good. Windows has nothing. But Windows has a third party tool called AutoHotkey, which was there for very long and allows to script the behavior of any input, with some very advanced logic.

Been using it for prob more than 3-4 years and my script that runs all the time on my pc has accumulated over 1000 lines from various small improvements
Friend: For example these lines, specifically only triggered when Adobe Acrobat is open saved me so much hassle
Friend: Adobe acrobat is very limited in key remappings, so with Autohotkey I can bypass that. Also the annoying copy paste behavior where it adds line breaks is annoying as hell, so this fixes it
Friend: Most of then I used for Mindmanager
Friend: But I have already made some for Logseq. Already quite a lot I had to make a hotkey to show available hotkeys
Friend: Perhaps you know anything similar on MacOS?

Friend: Am I doing it wrong?
Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.
Friend: So I am ready to give away this approach and the closes to it is the bulletjournal, which Roam or Logseq has. But still MindManager had a bunch of features I really utilized that I need to get ticket. Been trying to do it with Logseq mostly, but also been using Obsidian a bit don't he side. Once I go deep enough with Logseq, I will try Obsidian

Friend: Been using Mac for a while now and at work I like it. One thing that I have not found how to substitude from what I was used to on Windows is third-party software that allows endless behavior change of all keyboard and mouse inputs. 

In mac, the out of the box keybaord shortcut solution is pretty good. Windows has nothing. But Windows has a third party tool called AutoHotkey, which was there for very long and allows to script the behavior of any input, with some very advanced logic.

Been using it for prob more than 3-4 years and my script that runs all the time on my pc has accumulated over 1000 lines from various small improvements
Friend: For example these lines, specifically only triggered when Adobe Acrobat is open saved me so much hassle
Friend: Adobe acrobat is very limited in key remappings, so with Autohotkey I can bypass that. Also the annoying copy paste behavior where it adds line breaks is annoying as hell, so this fixes it
Friend: Most of then I used for Mindmanager
Friend: But I have already made some for Logseq. Already quite a lot I had to make a hotkey to show available hotkeys
Friend: Perhaps you know anything similar on MacOS?

Friend: Am I doing it wrong?
Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.
Friend: So I am ready to give away this approach and the closes to it is the bulletjournal, which Roam or Logseq has. But still MindManager had a bunch of features I really utilized that I need to get ticket. Been trying to do it with Logseq mostly, but also been using Obsidian a bit don't he side. Once I go deep enough with Logseq, I will try Obsidian
Friend: Actually I would really like Obsidian to fit my criteria, because it has much bigger community and seems more stable.
Friend: I will let you know in the end what I conclude
Friend: Is there something that you think Obsidian has unique? Also is there something you would like it to have? So I can have these things in mind.

Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.
Friend: So I am ready to give away this approach and the closes to it is the bulletjournal, which Roam or Logseq has. But still MindManager had a bunch of features I really utilized that I need to get ticket. Been trying to do it with Logseq mostly, but also been using Obsidian a bit don't he side. Once I go deep enough with Logseq, I will try Obsidian

Persona: Obedience to Authority
Friend: what happened?
Friend: Been using Mac for a while now and at work I like it. One thing that I have not found how to substitude from what I was used to on Windows is third-party software that allows endless behavior change of all keyboard and mouse inputs. 

In mac, the out of the box keybaord shortcut solution is pretty good. Windows has nothing. But Windows has a third party tool called AutoHotkey, which was there for very long and allows to script the behavior of any input, with some very advanced logic.

Been using it for prob more than 3-4 years and my script that runs all the time on my pc has accumulated over 1000 lines from various small improvements
Friend: For example these lines, specifically only triggered when Adobe Acrobat is open saved me so much hassle
Friend: Adobe acrobat is very limited in key remappings, so with Autohotkey I can bypass that. Also the annoying copy paste behavior where it adds line breaks is annoying as hell, so this fixes it
Friend: Most of then I used for Mindmanager
Friend: But I have already made some for Logseq. Already quite a lot I had to make a hotkey to show available hotkeys
Friend: Perhaps you know anything similar on MacOS?

Friend: Am I doing it wrong?
Friend: Man for the whole week I have been thinking deeply about this note-taking approach and I am giving it a lot of time, testing a bunch of tools, cause slowly I am realizing that mindmanager has had some lacking things and hasn't caught up on then for all 5 years I have been using it.
The main problems are that mobile support is basically read-only.
It has almost no community. So not much plugins, no support. Any plugins that exist are paid.
It's very expensive. ~19eur/month and yearly subscription only. I can't pirate it on work mac, cause rules :(
Through out 5 years of development that I witnessed, prettymuch almost no features were added. Just speed improvements. The spirit of the company making it seems dead.
Its hard to customize. idk on what its built, but there is little room for functionality customization compared to Loqseq and Obsidian for example, where you can just dig into the code.
Still no proper support for tables.
(not a necessary one) but no support for auto queries and databases (dataviews), that give some automation.
Friend: But there are also a lot of great features that I been using a lot and the whole approach to presentation is actually one-off unique to the whole note-taking tools. Obsidian is page based, Loqseq is a bulletjournal and MindManager is smth close to bulletjournal but with horizontal expansion.

I've searched 10s of times no other note-taking app as capable as the three of these here with horizontally expanding bulletjournal approach exist. All the other mindmapping software are highly inferior, not well made for it.
